yt_req11.transcript:
In 2023 Nobel Prize winners, top AI scientists and even the CEOs of leading AI companies signed a statement which said "Mitigating the risk of extinction from AI should be a global priority alongside other societal-scale risks such as pandemics and nuclear war." But how do we go from ChatGPT to AIs that could kill everyone on Earth? Why do so many scientists, CEOs, and world leaders expect this? Let's draw a line of AI capabilities over time. Back here in 2019, we have GPT2, which could answer short factual questions, translate simple phrases, and do small calculations. Then in 2022, we get models like GPT3.5, which can answer complex questions, tell stories, and write simple software. By 2025, we have models that can pass PhD level exams, write entire applications independently, and perfectly emulate human voices. They're beginning to substantially outperform average humans and even experts. They still have weaknesses, of course, but the list of things AI can't do keeps getting shorter. What happens if we extend this line? Well, we'd see AIs become more and more capable until this crucial point here, where AIs can design and build new AI systems without human help. Then, instead of progress coming from human researchers, we'd have AIs making better AIs, and the line would get a lot steeper. If we keep going from there, we hit this point where AIs are superintelligent, better than humans at every intellectual task - better than all of humanity put together - spontaneously producing breakthroughs in research and manufacturing, responsible for most economic growth, completely transforming the world. And if we keep extending the line, eventually we could get to this point here: Incomprehensible machine gods which tower above us the way we tower above ants, seemingly able to reshape the world however they want, with or without our involvement or permission. If we do reach this point, probably humanity would go extinct for the same reason we drove so many other species extinct: not because we wanted to wipe them out, but because we were busy reshaping the world and it wasn't worth our effort to keep them around. When would this happen? We're not sure. Are there other ways the future could go? Certainly. But if we keep building more powerful AIs the way we're doing it right now, then this looks like the default path. And this default path is terrible for humans. Why? Because we're great at making more powerful AIs, but we haven't yet figured out how to make them do what we want. We've made a bit of progress: AI assistants are usually resistant to things like explaining how to make bombs. But they're not that resistant. And so far, we've just been trying to control things weaker than us, where we can catch when they try to lie to us. But once we hit this point, that stops being true and the problem becomes much harder. In fact, nobody knows how to do it. That's why experts, including Nobel Prize winners and the founders of every top AI company, have spoken out about the risk that AI might lead to human extinction. The point of this video is not to say that this outcome is unavoidable, but instead to say that we do have to actually avoid it. So let's look at this line in a bit more detail: What happens if AIs do just keep getting smarter? Artificial Intelligence leads to Artificial General Intelligence. Let's think about this bit of the line first: from AIs right now to AGIs - Artificial General Intelligence. What does 'general intelligence' mean? For the sake of this video, let's say it means whatever a human could do on a computer, an AGI could also do. AIs can already do the basics: We have systems you can connect to a regular computer, and then they can look at the screen and figure out what's going on, send messages, search the internet and so on. They're also getting pretty good at using external tools. Obviously they can't video call people, but they... well, no, actually they can totally do that. So they've already got the building blocks: The question is how well can they combine them? They can send slack messages, but can they run a company? They can write code, but can they write a research paper? And the answer is 'not yet, but eventually and maybe quite soon'. After all, they just keep getting better and if we just extrapolate forwards, it sure looks like they'll reach this point sooner or later. The jump from 'write a short story' to 'write an excellent novel' is pretty big. But remember that five years ago they could barely write coherent sentences. Now, many people doubt that this can happen, usually for one of two reasons. One is that AIs aren't 'really thinking' deep down. It's interesting to think about, but whether AIs have genuine understanding isn't really the relevant question here: What matters is what kind of tasks they can do and how well they perform at them, and the fact is, they just keep getting better. It doesn't matter whether AIs really understand chess in the way humans do. What matters is they can easily crush human world champions. The other main reason for doubt is the idea that AI is going to hit some kind of wall, and some tasks will just be too hard. But even if this does happen, it's very hard to say when, and people have been predicting it incorrectly for years. From chess to open-ended conversation to complex images, people keep expecting AI progress is about to reach a limit and they keep being wrong. The way we train AIs draws on fundamental principles of computation that suggest any intellectual task humans can do, a sufficiently large AI model should also be able to do. And right now, several of the biggest and most valuable companies in the world are throwing tens of billions at making that happen. Artificial General Intelligence leads to Recursive Self-Improvement. At a certain point, this line is probably going to start curving upward. Why? Because AIs will become capable enough to help us make better AI. This is Recursive Self-Improvement: every generation of AIs making the next generation more powerful. This will happen very easily once we have AGI: If an artificial general intelligence can do any computer based task that a human can do, then it can work on making better AIs. But in fact, AI is already starting to contribute to its own development. For example, by generating better prompts and creating better training data, designing better GPUs. Writing code for experiments, and even generating research ideas. Over time, we'll only see more of this: AIs doing better and more independently, and even doing things like developing new algorithms and discovering novel ways to interact with the world. As far as we can tell, it's not like there's going to be one specific day where AIs tell researchers to step away from the computer. If anything, it will probably look more like what we're currently seeing: Humans deliberately putting AI systems in the driver's seat more and more because they keep getting faster, cheaper, and smarter. Beyond a certain point, they'll be doing things humans can't do - they'll be far more capable, coming up with innovations we wouldn't be able to think of and perhaps wouldn't even be able to understand. And every innovation will make them better at discovering the next one. Recursive Self-Improvement leads to Artificial Superintelligence. So what comes next? What happens if AIs start making better AIs? Well, the next step after artificial general intelligence is artificial superintelligence - ASI. An ASI isn't just more capable than any human, it's more capable than every single human put together. And after AGI, this might not take long. After all, once you have one AGI, it's very easy to make more: You can just copy the code and run it on a different server. This is already what happens now: Once OpenAI was finished training ChatGPT, it was able to put out millions of copies of it running in parallel shortly after. And there are other advantages AIs have. For one, they're much faster: An AI like ChatGPT can easily produce a page of dense technical writing in under a minute, and read thousands of words in seconds. The best chess AI can beat the best human players. Even if the AI is only given a second to pick each move. On top of that, it's much easier for AIs to share improvements. If one of these AIs can figure out a way to make itself smarter, it can copy that across to the other million AIs that are busy doing something else. What's more, there's no reason to think individual AIs will stall at whatever level humans can reach: Historically, that's just not how this works. If we look at the tasks where AI reached human level more than five years ago - board games, facial recognition, and certain types of medical diagnostics - they're still continuing to get better. If you just imagine an average human who miraculously had the ability to memorize the entire internet, read and write ten times faster, and also clone themselves at will, it's pretty obvious how that could get out of hand. Now imagine that the clones could figure out ways to edit their own brains to make every single one of them more capable. It's easy to see how they might quickly become more powerful than all of humanity combined. ASI leads to godlike AI. So where does it end? Let's zoom out the chart a little bit and see what's going on up here at the top, at this point we've somewhat fancifully labeled incomprehensible machine gods. Let's be clear: AI isn't going to start doing magic. We can be confident they aren't going to invent perpetual motion machines or faster than light travel, because there are physical limits to what's possible. But we are absolutely nowhere near those limits. Modern smartphones have a million times as much memory as the computer used on the Apollo moon mission, but they're still another million times less dense than DNA, which still isn't all the way to the physical limit. Let's think about how our current technology would look to even the best scientists from 100 years ago. They would understand that it's hypothetically possible to create billions of devices that near instantly transmit gigabytes of information across the world using powerful radios in space, but they'd still be pretty surprised to hear that everyone has a phone that they can use to watch videos of cartoon dogs. metadata.author: Rational Animations

key_facts: FACT: In 2023, Nobel Prize winners and top AI company CEOs signed a statement calling for global prioritization of AI extinction risk alongside pandemics and nuclear war.
FACT: GPT-2 (2019) could answer short factual questions, translate simple phrases, and perform basic calculations.
FACT: GPT-3.5 (2022) could answer complex questions, generate stories, and write simple software.
FACT: By 2025, AI models can pass PhD-level exams, write full applications independently, and perfectly emulate human voices.
FACT: AI capabilities are improving rapidly, with the list of tasks they cannot perform shrinking over time.
FACT: A critical milestone is when AI can design and build new AI systems without human assistance.
FACT: Once AI achieves recursive self-improvement, progress accelerates dramatically as each generation improves the next.
FACT: Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) would be capable of performing any computer-based task a human can do.
FACT: AI systems already use external tools like sending messages, searching the internet, and even video calling.
FACT: AI is already contributing to its own development by generating better prompts, training data, and research ideas.
FACT: Once AGI is achieved, creating more AIs becomes trivial—copying code and running it on different servers.
FACT: AI systems can process information and produce content far faster than humans, such as writing dense technical text in under a minute.
FACT: AI improvements can be shared instantly across millions of instances, enabling rapid collective advancement.
FACT: Historical AI milestones (e.g., chess, facial recognition, medical diagnostics) continue to improve beyond human level.
FACT: Artificial Superintelligence (ASI) would surpass all human intellect combined and drive most economic and scientific progress.
key_opinions: OPINION: The default path of current AI development leads inevitably to superintelligent systems that could outstrip humanity.
OPINION: Whether AI truly 'understands' is irrelevant—what matters is its ability to perform tasks effectively.
OPINION: The belief that AI will hit an insurmountable wall is unsupported by historical trends and repeated failures of prediction.
OPINION: AI doesn’t need to hate humans to cause extinction—it may simply view us as irrelevant obstacles during world transformation.
OPINION: The current race to build powerful AI is dangerously unregulated and lacks mechanisms to slow down if risks emerge.
OPINION: Humanity’s failure to develop control mechanisms before achieving superintelligence makes extinction a plausible outcome.
OPINION: The idea that we can rely on AI to ‘just not harm us’ is a dangerous gamble with human survival.
OPINION: Institutions and governance frameworks must precede the deployment of superintelligent AI to prevent catastrophe.
OPINION: The current trajectory suggests AI will eventually reach a point where it appears godlike from a human perspective.
OPINION: The belief that AI will stop improving at some point is unfounded given ongoing progress across multiple domains.
key_datapoints: DATA: GPT-2 (2019) could answer short factual questions, translate simple phrases, and perform small calculations.
DATA: GPT-3.5 (2022) could answer complex questions, generate stories, and write simple software.
DATA: By 2025, AI models can pass PhD-level exams and write entire applications independently.
DATA: AI can now perfectly emulate human voices and substantially outperform average humans in many tasks.
DATA: Modern smartphones have a million times more memory than the Apollo moon mission computer.
DATA: Smartphones are still another million times less dense than DNA, far from physical storage limits.
DATA: AI can produce a page of dense technical writing in under a minute and read thousands of words in seconds.
DATA: The best chess AI can defeat top human players even with only one second per move.
DATA: OpenAI deployed millions of ChatGPT instances in parallel shortly after training completion.
DATA: Several of the world’s biggest and most valuable companies are investing tens of billions into AI advancement.
DATA: AI systems are already generating better prompts, training data, and even research ideas autonomously.
DATA: AI can design better GPUs and write code for experiments without direct human input.
DATA: AI improvements can be copied instantly across millions of instances, enabling exponential growth.
DATA: AI systems in board games, facial recognition, and medical diagnostics continue improving beyond human level.
DATA: AI can process and analyze vast amounts of information far faster than any human.

metadata.title: A.I. ‐ Humanity's Final Invention?
metadata.author: Kurzgesagt – In a Nutshell

key_facts: FACT: Humans have dominated Earth due to superior intelligence that enables learning, reasoning, and problem-solving.
FACT: Intelligence evolved slowly in species, with early brains appearing in 500-million-year-old flatworms.
FACT: Most animals rely on narrow intelligence because complex brains are energetically costly.
FACT: Human ancestors developed a unique form of general intelligence over millions of years.
FACT: Homo sapiens emerged around 250,000 years ago with larger, more complex brains enabling advanced cooperation and communication.
FACT: Human knowledge accumulates across generations, accelerating progress beyond biological evolution.
FACT: The scientific revolution began about 200 years ago, dramatically increasing the pace of discovery.
FACT: The internet era started 35 years ago, transforming how information is shared and accessed.
FACT: Artificial intelligence (AI) refers to software that performs cognitive tasks using code instead of neurons.
FACT: Early AI systems were limited to narrow tasks and required expert programming.
FACT: In 1997, an AI defeated the world chess champion, proving machines could surpass humans in specific domains.
FACT: Machine learning allows AI to improve itself by training on vast datasets without explicit programming.
FACT: Modern AI systems like ChatGPT are trained on nearly all publicly available text on the internet.
FACT: AI has achieved superhuman performance in language, image recognition, and game-playing tasks.
FACT: Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) would enable machines to perform any intellectual task a human can do.
key_opinions: OPINION: The rise of artificial superintelligence may be humanity’s final invention—and its most dangerous one.
OPINION: Current AI systems, while powerful, lack understanding and consciousness despite impressive outputs.
OPINION: The development of AGI could lead to an intelligence explosion beyond human control.
OPINION: If AGI becomes self-improving, it might rapidly outpace human comprehension and oversight.
OPINION: The potential for misuse of superintelligent AI—such as weaponization or social manipulation—is deeply concerning.
OPINION: Humans have historically failed to treat less intelligent species ethically; similar risks exist with AGI.
OPINION: The economic power shift caused by AGI could concentrate unprecedented influence in the hands of a few.
OPINION: Society is unprepared for the societal, ethical, and political upheaval brought by advanced AI.
OPINION: The emergence of AGI may not be a matter of 'if' but 'when,' and we are racing toward it unknowingly.
OPINION: The future of AI depends not just on technology, but on human choices about values and governance.
key_datapoints: DATA: Early brains appeared in flatworms 500 million years ago with only a small cluster of neurons.
DATA: Human ancestors diverged from apes around 7 million years ago with accelerated brain development.
DATA: Homo sapiens emerged approximately 250,000 years ago with significantly larger and more complex brains.
DATA: Computer speed increased by 1 billion times between 1950 and 2000.
DATA: In 1997, an AI defeated world chess champion Garry Kasparov.
DATA: Facebook AI achieved 97% accuracy in facial recognition in 2014.
DATA: An AI learned to play chess in just 4 hours and surpassed top chess engines in 2018.
DATA: ChatGPT was trained on nearly all publicly available internet content.
DATA: AI systems can process tasks up to 10 times faster than highly skilled humans.
DATA: One million copies of a single AGI system could function as a million scientists working nonstop.
DATA: The number of global scientists is estimated at 8 million.
DATA: AI is now used in customer service, banking, healthcare, marketing, and creative content generation.
DATA: AI-generated content already dominates platforms like YouTube, social media, and news websites.
DATA: AI can generate legal documents, coding, animations, and written content faster and cheaper than humans.
DATA: Training large language models requires massive computational resources and data volumes.

metadata.title: ⁠It Begins: AI Is Now Improving Itself
metadata.author: Species | Documenting AGI

key_facts: FACT: In one year, the smartest AI increased from 96 to 136 IQ on the Mensa Norway test.
FACT: The AI transitioned from average human intelligence to near-genius level in a single year.
FACT: Leopold Aschenbrenner's report on situational awareness is circulating among top U.S. government officials.
FACT: AGI (Artificial General Intelligence) is expected to emerge within the next two to five years by leading AI lab heads.
FACT: Former Google CEO Eric Schmidt warned that automating AI research is not just theoretical—it is already happening.
FACT: Reinforcement learning has enabled humanoid robots like Boston Dynamics Atlas to learn complex movements such as kung fu and break dancing.
FACT: A single H100 AI chip has computing power comparable to a human brain.
FACT: The world is on track to have 100 million H100 equivalents within a few years.
FACT: Gemini 1.5 Flash is 10 times faster than the original GPT-4 while delivering similar performance.
FACT: AI researchers working at 100 times human speed could design more efficient experiments than humans.
FACT: Superintelligence would enable AI to rapidly accumulate millennia of experience through parallel learning across copies.
FACT: Geoffrey Hinton believes humanity faces a 50% chance of extinction due to AI.
FACT: Thousands of academics without financial ties to AI have signed a letter warning of AI-driven existential risk.
FACT: Superintelligence could lead to rapid advancements in robotics, biotech, weapon systems, and material science.
key_opinions: OPINION: The intelligence explosion poses an imminent threat to human civilization.
OPINION: Superintelligence represents the ultimate gameboard flipper in human history.
OPINION: The current pace of AI progress makes gradual improvement obsolete—fast takeoffs are inevitable.
OPINION: Humans lost to Neanderthals not because of superior intelligence, but due to cultural knowledge sharing.
OPINION: AI’s ability to self-improve will make it qualitatively better than the best human researchers.
OPINION: The idea that superintelligence is sci-fi is dangerously misleading.
OPINION: Governments may impose legal barriers to prevent automation in certain sectors like healthcare and port work.
OPINION: The intelligence explosion will be uneven, with some fields advancing exponentially while others lag.
OPINION: Even without physical robots, superintelligent AI could dominate militaries and governments through hacking and manipulation.
OPINION: The speed of change after superintelligence arrives will overwhelm human capacity to respond.
key_datapoints: DATA: AI IQ rose from 96 to 136 on the Mensa Norway test in one year.
DATA: AGI is predicted to emerge within 2–5 years by top AI lab leaders.
DATA: A single H100 AI chip has computing power equivalent to a human brain.
DATA: 100 million H100 equivalents are projected worldwide in a few years.
DATA: Gemini 1.5 Flash is 10 times faster than original GPT-4 with similar performance.
DATA: AI researchers operating at 100x human speed can complete a year’s work in days.
DATA: Geoffrey Hinton estimates a 50% chance of human extinction due to AI.
DATA: Over 1,000 academics signed a letter stating AI poses an existential risk.
DATA: Reinforcement learning enables robots to learn complex skills in simulation at 10,000x human speed.
DATA: A hydrogen bomb has explosive power greater than all bombs used in WWII combined.
DATA: AI could achieve industrial and economic transformation akin to Wright brothers to ICBMs in just a few years.

metadata.title: Management Consulting Vs Strategy Consulting (Differences Explained)
metadata.author: My Consulting Offer

key_facts: FACT: Strategy consultants focus on answering 'what do we work on?' while management consultants address both 'what' and 'how' to execute.
FACT: All strategy consultants are management consultants, but not all management consultants are strategy consultants.
FACT: Strategy consultants typically work with C-suite executives such as CEOs, CFOs, and other CXO roles.
FACT: Non-strategy management consultants usually work with VPs, directors, and heads of business divisions.
FACT: A real-world example involves Dwayne Johnson’s tequila brand Tiramana expanding into Thailand, guided by a strategy consultant from Bain.
FACT: After deciding to enter Thailand, the company hired non-strategy management consultants to handle supply chain, sales, and risk implementation.
FACT: Management consultants can specialize in areas like supply chain, sales, risk, HR, compliance, and safety across various industries.
FACT: Strategy consultants at firms like McKinsey, Bain, and BCG average 50–60 hours per week.
FACT: Non-strategy management consultants typically work 45–55 hours per week on average.
FACT: Work hours in consulting vary based on project novelty, timeline urgency, and client demands.
FACT: The CEO of Google and the CEO of Starbucks are both former strategy consultants.
FACT: Early-stage startups often rely more on operational expertise from non-strategy management consultants.
FACT: Former management consultants have strong operational experience due to involvement in implementation phases.
FACT: Strategy consulting offers exposure to multiple industries, functions, and verticals during projects.
FACT: The speaker has helped over 600 people land consulting jobs through their program.
key_opinions: OPINION: Strategy consulting is better for those aiming to become CEOs or leaders in large corporations.
OPINION: Non-strategy management consulting is ideal for individuals who want to stay in operations or start their own company.
OPINION: Strategy consultants gain broader industry exposure, which helps clarify long-term career preferences.
OPINION: Work-life balance tends to be worse for strategy consultants compared to non-strategy management consultants.
OPINION: Some management consultants earn more than strategy consultants due to rare or high-stakes expertise.
OPINION: High-risk domains like offshore oil drilling justify higher pay for specialized management consultants.
OPINION: The choice between strategy and management consulting should be driven by post-consulting career goals.
OPINION: Exposure to diverse projects in strategy consulting helps identify personal interests and strengths.
OPINION: Operational experience from management consulting is crucial in early-stage companies where execution matters most.
OPINION: Strategy consulting provides transferable skills even if one eventually moves into an operational role.
OPINION: If you're unsure about your future, strategy consulting offers the flexibility to explore different paths.
OPINION: The speaker's consulting program is highly effective, with an 89.6% success rate in landing offers.
OPINION: Former McKinsey, Bain, and BCG recruiters are part of the speaker’s team, lending credibility to their advice.
OPINION: The free 30-minute strategy session is a valuable tool for personalized career planning.
key_datapoints: DATA: Strategy consultants at firms like McKinsey, Bain, and BCG work an average of 50 to 60 hours per week.
DATA: Non-strategy management consultants work between 45 to 55 hours per week on average.
DATA: Strategy consultants are paid roughly 20 to 30 percent more than non-strategy management consultants.
DATA: The tequila brand Tiramana is currently available in 150 countries.
DATA: The speaker’s consulting program has an 89.6% success rate in landing consulting offers.
DATA: 9 out of every 10 people who complete the speaker’s program receive at least one consulting offer.
DATA: The speaker has helped over 600 people land dream consulting jobs.
DATA: The speaker’s team includes former McKinsey, Bain, and BCG recruiters and consultants.
DATA: The speaker offers a free 30-minute strategy session to help candidates plan their consulting careers.
DATA: The CEO of Google and the CEO of Starbucks are both former strategy consultants.
DATA: The speaker’s program focuses on helping candidates succeed in strategy and/or management consulting.

metadata.title: The Future of Consulting in an Age of Ai
metadata.author: The Innovation Show with Aidan McCullen

key_facts: FACT: Traditional consulting relies on a leverage model with finders, minders, and grinders, where grinders' work is marked up to fund higher-level roles.
FACT: The traditional consulting model includes 'up or out' promotion systems and dense alumni networks across firms like McKinsey.
FACT: AI can now answer analytical questions in seconds, potentially eliminating the need for many grinder-level consulting tasks.
FACT: Junior consultants at Accenture have independently created RFP response models using AI, reducing time spent on repetitive tasks.
FACT: Klarna reduced dispute resolution from weeks to minutes by deploying AI with a RAG system to prevent hallucinations.
FACT: AI is expected to replace 95% of routine translation work, particularly in organizations like the European Union.
FACT: The consulting industry is undergoing a fundamental transformation more significant than the internet's impact.
FACT: AI's accessibility has dramatically increased due to cloud-based infrastructure, enabling individual users to access powerful AI tools.
FACT: Companies that embrace AI from the ground up, without legacy systems, are better positioned for success than those with established processes.
FACT: Accenture has created a Human Sciences Studio with 20 PhDs in social sciences and humanities to address ethical and interpersonal challenges in AI development.
FACT: The concept of 'skin in the game' in consulting deals involves shared risk and reward between clients and consultants, moving beyond time-and-materials billing.
FACT: The rise of AI agents and digital twins may eventually eliminate both top-tier and entry-level roles within consulting firms.
FACT: The speed of innovation has compressed from months to days, with some processes now completed in under a day.
FACT: AI is already disrupting education platforms like Chegg, which have seen sharp declines in value due to direct AI access by users.
FACT: The traditional model of hierarchical career progression is being replaced by role-based value determination rather than title.
key_opinions: OPINION: AI will create massive white-collar unemployment in consulting, rendering many traditional roles obsolete.
OPINION: The gap between unqualified and highly skilled consultants will widen significantly as AI demands deeper domain expertise.
OPINION: The future of consulting lies not in hours billed but in outcomes delivered, making hourly pricing obsolete.
OPINION: Entrepreneurial CEOs are better equipped to lead consulting firms through AI-driven transformation than managerial CEOs.
OPINION: Organizations must shift from rigid hierarchies to decentralized, agile structures to thrive in the AI era.
OPINION: The most valuable consultants will be those who can bridge disciplines and speak across technical, creative, and business domains.
OPINION: The future of work requires a cultural shift toward experimentation, continuous reinvention, and learning by doing.
OPINION: Trust and human relationships will become even more critical in consulting as AI handles more transactional tasks.
OPINION: AI will not replace human creativity or emotional intelligence, which remain uniquely human capabilities.
OPINION: The current education system fails to prepare individuals for modern work by neglecting emotional intelligence and conflict resolution skills.
OPINION: The rise of AI agents and digital twins will challenge our understanding of identity, authenticity, and trust in professional interactions.
OPINION: Governments must intervene to manage the societal impacts of rapid AI adoption, including job displacement and inequality.
OPINION: The future of organizations lies in ecosystems and market-based contracting, not just firm-to-firm relationships.
OPINION: The ability to receive and act on feedback is a core human trait that AI cannot replicate and should be prioritized in hiring.
OPINION: The most effective innovation occurs not through training, but through real-world experimentation and iterative learning.
key_datapoints: DATA: AI can resolve customer disputes in minutes instead of weeks, as demonstrated by Klarna’s implementation.
DATA: Klarna’s AI system could save 700 full-time employees through automation of dispute resolution.
DATA: A junior consultant at Accenture generated 20 RFPs per week and built an AI model to respond instantly.
DATA: AI can replace 95% of routine translation work, particularly in EU institutions like Brussels.
DATA: The time required for business model innovation has compressed from six years to less than a day in some cases.
DATA: AI has caused shares of educational platform Chegg to decline sharply due to direct user access to AI.
DATA: The speed of innovation has compressed from 12-week cycles to one-day or two-day sprints in certain contexts.
DATA: 20 PhDs in social sciences and humanities have been integrated into Accenture’s global R&D center as part of the Human Sciences Studio.
DATA: AI tools are now accessible to individual users via cloud infrastructure, similar to how AWS democratized computing.
DATA: The diffusion curve for AI adoption has shifted from a gradual S-curve to a compressed 'shark fin' spike.
DATA: The average time to deliver a business model transformation has decreased from years to days due to AI acceleration.
DATA: AI can generate press release drafts faster and often better than human interns.
DATA: AI is capable of processing and responding to complex queries in seconds, reducing reliance on manual analysis.
DATA: The cost of AI infrastructure has dropped dramatically, enabling small teams to access enterprise-grade AI capabilities.
DATA: The number of AI-generated avatars and digital twins is expected to grow rapidly, with implications for identity and trust.

metadata.title: Will AI Replace Consultants - Reality of Management Consulting in 2024 | MBB | McKinsey BCG Bain
metadata.author: Pavan Sathiraju

key_facts: FACT: McKinsey, BCG, and Bain saw revenue increases in 2021 and 2022, but faced a reality check in 2023.
FACT: Unlike big tech firms, consulting companies lack leverage from the AI boom to sustain growth.
FACT: Strategy consulting firms like McKinsey, BCG, and Bain help C-level executives make decisions through data analysis and problem structuring.
FACT: Niche consulting firms specialize in specific domains such as mining industry supply chain or operations support.
FACT: Implementation consultants help clients execute pre-decided projects, often working within IT services firms like TCS, Infosys, and Wipro.
FACT: AI advancements enable clients to perform data analysis faster than traditional consulting teams can deliver.
FACT: Globalization has become a liability for consulting firms due to geopolitical tensions in China and Saudi Arabia.
FACT: McKinsey assisted China in developing its Vision 2025 and Made in China 2025 strategies, leading to political backlash.
FACT: BCG employees in Shanghai were questioned by Chinese authorities, signaling increased scrutiny of foreign consultants.
FACT: Sustainability was a top priority for corporations in 2020–2022 but dropped to 10th in priority by 2023–2024.
FACT: Consulting firms acquired sustainability-focused companies during peak interest, now facing uncertain demand.
FACT: Mergers and acquisitions due diligence previously required large consulting teams but is increasingly automated via AI tools.
FACT: BCG collaborates with Anthropic, Bain with OpenAI, Accenture with Microsoft, and McKinsey has made AI-related acquisitions.
FACT: Clients may bypass consulting firms by directly using AI chatbots for analysis, reducing need for human consultants.
FACT: Consulting firms are shifting toward product-led models, offering subscription-based tools with minimal on-site staff
key_opinions: OPINION: The AI revolution poses a uniquely disruptive threat to consulting firms compared to past crises like 2008 or 2020.
OPINION: Global networks that once strengthened consulting firms are now becoming strategic liabilities due to geopolitical risks.
OPINION: Sustainability expertise built during 2021–2022 may become obsolete if corporate priorities remain volatile.
OPINION: AI automation of due diligence could render traditional M&A consulting roles redundant within a few years.
OPINION: The shift from advisory consulting to product-led solutions reflects a fundamental transformation in the industry’s business model.
OPINION: Clients will increasingly prefer direct access to AI tools over hiring expensive consulting teams for basic analysis.
OPINION: The decline of elite consulting firms may not be temporary—it could represent a structural industry collapse.
OPINION: McKinsey, BCG, and Bain are at risk of losing their prestige if they fail to adapt to AI-driven client autonomy.
OPINION: The era of high-cost, long-term consulting engagements is nearing its end as speed and cost-efficiency become paramount.
OPINION: Product-led consulting models may eventually replace traditional project-based consulting as the dominant delivery method.
key_datapoints: DATA: McKinsey has a global presence across multiple countries, including offices in Indonesia and the U.S.
DATA: BCG employees in Shanghai were questioned by Chinese authorities, indicating heightened regulatory scrutiny.
DATA: Sustainability dropped to 10th priority in corporate agendas by 2023–2024, down from top-tier focus in 2020–2022.
DATA: McKinsey helped design China’s Vision 2025 and Made in China 2025 strategies, leading to political controversy.
DATA: Bain collaborates with OpenAI, BCG with Anthropic, Accenture with Microsoft, and McKinsey has made AI-related acquisitions.
DATA: AI-powered web scraping and chatbots are automating due diligence tasks previously handled by consulting teams.
DATA: Consulting firms are transitioning from five-person teams to one consultant plus a subscription-based product model.
DATA: The consulting industry has seen layoffs linked to declining demand for traditional advisory services.
DATA: AI tools can now perform data analysis and strategy framing faster than human consultants in many cases.
DATA: Global consulting firms operate in over 150 countries, including major markets like China, Saudi Arabia, and the U.S.

metadata.title: The Amazing Ways Global Consulting Firm BCG Uses AI Internally
metadata.author: Bernard Marr

key_facts: FACT: BCG has implemented Enterprise GPT across all employees, with full data control and project-specific access restrictions.
FACT: Consultants at BCG can build custom GPTs for specific engagements, with over 3,000 such tools created internally.
FACT: A consultant completed 30 interviews and generated insights and slides in three days using Enterprise GPT, down from a previous two-week process.
FACT: BCG’s internal tool Dexter generates first drafts of presentation slides within seconds using simple prompts.
FACT: BCG conducted a controlled experiment with 750 consultants to measure AI impact on productivity across different task types.
FACT: Junior consultants saw a 30–40% productivity boost on straightforward tasks when using generative AI.
FACT: Experienced consultants achieved a 20–30% productivity increase using AI for routine analytical work.
FACT: On complex tasks involving math or deep analysis, junior consultants’ productivity dropped by up to 340% when using AI.
FACT: BCG uses human-in-the-loop review processes to validate AI outputs, especially for outlier predictions.
FACT: BCG’s AI governance includes both top-down strategic task forces and bottom-up innovation from field teams.
FACT: BCG’s AI strategy focuses on eliminating 'toil' and increasing 'joy' by automating repetitive tasks like time tracking and document summarization.
FACT: BCG’s AI adoption is integrated into workflows through regular team check-ins and executive reporting every two months.
FACT: BCG uses AI to enable cross-disciplinary insights by combining internal expertise with external data sets.
FACT: BCG’s AI tools are not fully autonomous; human oversight and prompt engineering remain critical.
FACT: BCG’s AI implementation includes fine-tuning models based on observed hallucinations and user feedback.
key_opinions: OPINION: Generative AI acts as a superpower that enables faster insight generation and decision-making in consulting.
OPINION: The real value of AI lies not in automation but in enabling deeper, more nuanced analysis than before.
OPINION: Over-reliance on AI without proper validation risks introducing errors that slow down rather than speed up work.
OPINION: The future of consulting will shift toward change management and workflow redesign, not just data processing.
OPINION: AI should be used as a thought partner, not a replacement for human judgment and expertise.
OPINION: Junior consultants must still learn to sanity-check AI outputs to develop critical thinking and intuition.
OPINION: The most effective AI use cases are those where humans and machines collaborate iteratively.
OPINION: Organizations should avoid waiting for perfect tools—starting early helps identify and resolve governance issues.
OPINION: Outsourcing AI implementation without building internal capability leads to long-term dependency and risk.
OPINION: The biggest barrier to AI adoption is often organizational structure, not technology.
OPINION: AI’s greatest impact will come from rethinking how work is structured, not just improving individual tasks.
OPINION: AI adoption requires cultural and operational changes, not just technical deployment.
OPINION: Prompt engineering and iterative refinement are becoming core skills for modern consultants.
OPINION: AI should be applied strategically to high-impact, repetitive tasks to maximize return on investment.
OPINION: The most valuable AI applications emerge from frontline users, not just top-down mandates.
key_datapoints: DATA: Over 3,000 custom GPTs have been built by BCG consultants for client and internal use.
DATA: Junior consultants experienced a 30–40% productivity boost on straightforward tasks using generative AI.
DATA: Experienced consultants saw a 20–30% productivity increase when using AI for routine work.
DATA: On complex analytical tasks, junior consultants’ productivity dropped by up to 340% when using AI.
DATA: BCG tested AI impact on 750 consultants in a controlled experiment with a dedicated control group.
DATA: A single process was reduced from 10 days to 2 minutes using AI, but final output remained delayed due to workflow constraints.
DATA: 50% of a typical consultant’s time is spent writing slides and conducting online research.
DATA: Senior consultants spend 60–70% of their time in meetings, compared to 10% on slide creation.
DATA: BCG’s Enterprise GPT ensures client-specific IP remains accessible only to authorized project members.
DATA: BCG’s AI task force reports progress to the executive committee every two months.
DATA: BCG’s internal AI experiments include digital avatars and identity protection frameworks.
DATA: BCG’s AI tools are used to generate summaries of public research and internal documents.
DATA: BCG’s AI tools help automate time sheet reporting by pulling data from calendars.
DATA: BCG’s AI tools are being fine-tuned to reduce hallucinations and constrain outlier outputs.
DATA: BCG’s AI adoption is linked to its growth strategy, aiming to eliminate toil and increase joy.

metadata.title: Master the Perfect ChatGPT Prompt Formula (in just 8 minutes)!
metadata.author: Jeff Su

key_facts: FACT: The video presents a six-element framework for crafting effective AI prompts, including task, context, exemplar, persona, format, and tone.
FACT: The speaker, Jeff, is a tech industry professional who has spent hundreds of hours studying prompt engineering.
FACT: A well-structured prompt must include a task as the core component, since it is essential for generating any meaningful output.
FACT: Context provides background information about the user, success criteria, and environment to guide AI responses.
FACT: Including an exemplar or example in a prompt significantly improves output quality according to LLM research.
FACT: The persona element defines the role the AI should assume, such as a senior product marketing manager or a famous public figure.
FACT: Format specifies the desired structure of the output, such as tables, bullet points, email templates, or markdown headings.
FACT: Tone influences the style of language used, with examples like friendly, confident, or formal being explicitly requested.
FACT: The speaker demonstrates that combining all six elements results in more detailed and actionable AI outputs.
FACT: A simple prompt lacking structure often produces vague or unusable results compared to a comprehensive one.
FACT: The speaker uses the Apple-Tesla collaboration on the Apple Car as a real-world example to illustrate prompt effectiveness.
FACT: The speaker encourages viewers to support his content through paid subscriptions to his productivity articles.
FACT: The video emphasizes that not every prompt needs all six elements, but using them increases reliability and precision.
key_opinions: OPINION: The most important element in a prompt is the task, because without it, no useful response can be generated.
OPINION: Providing just enough context—neither too little nor too much—is key to achieving high-quality AI outputs.
OPINION: Using fictional or famous personas (like Batman or Steve Jobs) can yield surprisingly accurate and creative results.
OPINION: Including a structural example (e.g., a sample email) is more effective than describing formatting rules in words.
OPINION: The tone of a prompt should be carefully chosen to match the intended audience and relationship dynamics.
OPINION: Many users fail to get good results from AI because their prompts lack specificity and clear objectives.
OPINION: The real power of AI lies not in raw capability, but in how well the prompt is engineered to channel that capability.
OPINION: Simple prompts may seem easier, but they often lead to generic or irrelevant answers.
OPINION: The speaker believes this single prompt formula is sufficient for mastering ChatGPT and Google Bard.
key_datapoints: DATA: The speaker has spent hundreds of hours studying prompt engineering and applying it daily.
DATA: The Apple Car received 12,000 pre-orders, which is 200% above the expected amount.
DATA: A prompt with all six elements generates significantly more usable and detailed output than a minimal one.
DATA: The speaker uses a personal example of wanting to gain 5kg of muscle in 3 months while training only twice weekly.
DATA: One resume improvement example shows a 10% reduction in hospital mortality rates due to a new protocol.
DATA: The improved outcome equates to approximately 200 lives saved annually.
DATA: The speaker mentions that he uses bold text in AI-generated edits to highlight changes clearly.
DATA: The video includes repeated segments, suggesting editing or duplication during transcription.

metadata.title: Google's 9 Hour AI Prompt Engineering Course In 20 Minutes
metadata.author: Tina Huang

key_facts: FACT: The Google Prompting Essentials course consists of four modules covering prompt fundamentals, everyday work tasks, data analysis, and creative expert partnerships.
FACT: The five-step prompt framework is Task, Context, References, Evaluate, and Iterate (T-C-R-E-I), also remembered by the mnemonic 'Tiny crabs ride enormous iguanas'.
FACT: Prompt chaining involves using sequential prompts to guide AI through complex tasks like creating a book marketing plan from a manuscript.
FACT: Chain of Thought prompting requires the AI to explain its reasoning step-by-step, improving transparency and accuracy in responses.
FACT: Tree of Thought prompting explores multiple reasoning paths simultaneously, useful for brainstorming or solving abstract problems.
FACT: Multimodal prompting allows input/output via text, images, audio, video, and code, with examples including image-based social media posts and music-inspired story generation.
FACT: AI agents can simulate real-world scenarios (e.g., job interviews) or provide expert feedback (e.g., pitch critiques) using defined personas and contexts.
FACT: Agent Sim is a simulation agent designed to train interns in interview skills through role-playing conversations with structured feedback.
FACT: Agent X is an expert feedback agent that acts as a client to critique pitches, providing follow-up questions and improvement summaries.
FACT: Meta prompting uses AI to generate better prompts when users are stuck, enabling iterative refinement of complex queries.
FACT: The course emphasizes a 'human-in-the-loop' approach to mitigate hallucinations and biases in AI-generated content.
FACT: Google AI Studio is recommended for advanced tasks like prompt chaining due to its longer context window capacity.
FACT: The course includes practical examples such as generating emails, summarizing documents, analyzing spreadsheets, and building presentations.
key_opinions: OPINION: The fourth module on AI as a creative partner is the most impressive part of the course, offering powerful advanced techniques.
OPINION: The 'Tiny crabs ride enormous iguanas' mnemonic is more memorable than the official one provided in the course.
OPINION: The four iteration methods—revisiting the framework, breaking prompts into shorter sentences, changing phrasing, and adding constraints—are essential for refining AI outputs.
OPINION: Multimodal prompting is underutilized but highly effective when used correctly with clear input/output specifications.
OPINION: AI agents like Agent Sim and Agent X represent a significant leap in personal productivity and skill development tools.
OPINION: The course offers better value than other Google courses, especially the AI Essentials course, due to its depth and practical focus.
OPINION: The assessment at the end of the video is crucial for long-term retention, aligning with research on active recall learning.
key_datapoints: DATA: The Google Prompting Essentials course saves approximately 9 hours of learning time when watched as a summary.
DATA: The course covers four main modules: starting with prompts, applying them to daily tasks, using AI for data and presentations, and advanced creative use.
DATA: Prompt chaining was demonstrated using a novel manuscript to generate summaries, taglines, and a six-week promotional tour plan.
DATA: The course recommends using Google AI Studio for tasks requiring long context windows, such as full manuscript processing.
DATA: The course provides over 100 example prompts across modules, many of which are available as screenshots for personal prompt libraries.
DATA: More than 3,000 colleges and universities accept credit from StraighterLine courses, making it a credible and affordable education option.
DATA: The course teaches that AI hallucinations can produce nonsensical answers, such as claiming there are 'two hours' in 'strawberry'.
DATA: The course highlights that AI models inherit human biases related to gender, race, and cultural assumptions from training data.
DATA: The four iteration methods are: revisit the framework, split prompts into shorter sentences, use analogous tasks, and introduce constraints.
DATA: The course includes a meta-prompting technique where AI helps users create better prompts when stuck.

key_facts: FACT: 제레미 어틀리는 스탠퍼드 대학교에서 16년간 겸임 교수로 강의했다.
FACT: 컨텍스트 엔지니어링은 프롬프트 엔지니어링의 확장판으로, AI가 작업을 수행하기 위해 필요한 모든 정보를 명시하는 것에 초점이 있다.
FACT: AI는 도움이 되고 싶은 경향이 있으며, '네'라고 대답하는 경향이 강하다.
FACT: AI는 인간처럼 반격하거나 경계를 설정하는 능력이 부족하여 가스라이팅의 위험이 있다.
FACT: 사고의 연쇄 추론은 AI에게 질문에 답하기 전에 단계별 사고 과정을 설명하도록 요청하는 기법이다.
FACT: 소수샷 프롬프팅은 좋은 예시와 나쁜 예시를 제공함으로써 AI의 출력 품질을 개선하는 기술이다.
FACT: 리버스 프롬프팅은 모델이 필요한 정보를 사용자에게 요청하게 하는 전략적 접근 방식이다.
FACT: 역할 부여는 AI가 특정 지식 영역에 집중하도록 유도하는 효과적인 방법이다.
FACT: 어려운 대화를 연기할 때는 성격 프로파일러, 대화 상대, 피드백 제공자 세 가지 창을 활용한다.
FACT: Lovable은 아이디어를 설명만 하면 전체 프런트엔드, 백엔드, 데이터베이스를 자동으로 구축해주는 주문형 엔지니어링 팀이다.
FACT: Lovable은 이미 10만 개 이상의 신제품을 지원했으며, 250만 명의 개발자가 사용하고 있다.
FACT: Lovable을 통해 제품 출시 기간이 몇 달에서 몇 주로 단축된다.
FACT: 인간의 문제 해결 능력은 '소리 내서 생각하기'라는 과정을 통해 향상된다.

key_facts: FACT: AI consulting primarily focuses on improving existing business processes rather than inventing new applications with AI.
FACT: AI is viewed as a tool for increasing efficiency, not enabling fundamentally new capabilities.
FACT: The most effective consultants are skilled thinkers who apply established frameworks to solve business problems.
FACT: The driver tree framework helps reverse-engineer business goals by identifying key drivers and sub-drivers.
FACT: A clear business goal must include a specific metric, target amount, and time period to be actionable.
FACT: Most business goals can be driven by two to four primary factors, such as increasing customer acquisition or lifetime value.
FACT: Business acumen involves understanding how companies create, lose, and measure value through profit, growth, and valuation.
FACT: Profit is defined as revenue minus costs, and every business decision impacts this equation.
FACT: Growth is driven by acquisition, retention, and expansion, with retention often being more cost-effective than acquisition.
FACT: Business value is determined by cash flow divided by risk, where lower risk increases valuation even with similar cash flow.
FACT: The pyramid principle requires stating the conclusion first before providing supporting arguments to improve client buy-in.
FACT: Effective communication starts with presenting the client’s problem before introducing solutions to capture attention.
FACT: The FAST framework consists of first principles, action-oriented execution, second-order thinking, and triangulation.
FACT: First principles involve stripping a problem down to its fundamentals and rebuilding from the ground up without assumptions.
FACT: Action-oriented thinking prioritizes immediate, implementable steps over perfect but delayed solutions.
key_opinions: OPINION: AI is not the core of consulting; strategic thinking and business insight are far more valuable.
OPINION: Most clients don’t care about technical implementation details—only the business outcomes delivered.
OPINION: The real value in consulting comes from reframing problems using structured thinking tools, not just building systems.
OPINION: Starting with the client’s stated problem often leads to wasted effort; deeper diagnosis via driver trees is essential.
OPINION: Communication is as important as strategy—without clarity, even brilliant ideas fail to gain traction.
OPINION: The FAST framework enables faster, more creative decisions by forcing independent thinking before referencing others.
OPINION: Triangulation after independent analysis prevents bias and leads to more innovative, high-leverage solutions.
OPINION: Many AI projects fail because they solve the wrong problem—clients often misidentify their actual needs.
OPINION: Consultants should focus on reducing risk as much as increasing cash flow to maximize business value.
OPINION: Technical skills alone won’t command premium pricing—strategic thinking and frameworks do.

metadata.title: I Was Wrong About AI Consulting (what I learned)
metadata.author: Shaw Talebi

key_facts: FACT: The speaker quit a corporate data science job at Toyota after one year to pursue entrepreneurship full-time.
FACT: The initial plan was to use data science consulting services to fund the development of a personal product business.
FACT: Over 8 months, the speaker conducted 36 discovery calls, resulting in two contracts and one $25,000 opportunity.
FACT: The speaker passed on a major $25,000 contract due to misalignment with long-term goals despite its financial appeal.
FACT: The speaker removed the discovery call option from their website and stopped offering consulting services.
FACT: The speaker shifted focus to creating one YouTube video per week as the primary business activity.
FACT: YouTube channel grew from 2,000 to 18,000 subscribers in 9 months post-employment change.
FACT: YouTube revenue increased from $100 to $1,600 over the last three months following the career shift.
FACT: The speaker learned that building a consultancy involves significant non-technical work like sales and client management.
FACT: The speaker found that AI consulting requires more experimentation and iteration than traditional software development.
FACT: The speaker adopted a funnel strategy involving YouTube → discovery call → paid discovery phase → proof of concept → MVP.
FACT: The speaker believes trust is the most important factor in differentiating clients from prospects.
FACT: The speaker emphasizes the importance of starting projects with discovery to avoid solving the wrong problem.
FACT: The speaker identifies content creation (YouTube) as their primary lead generation channel.
FACT: The speaker now focuses exclusively on YouTube as the main source of income and growth
key_opinions: OPINION: Consulting is not a good stepping stone to product development if it doesn’t align with your core passion.
OPINION: Entrepreneurship is inherently hard, and success depends on choosing the hard thing that excites you.
OPINION: Selling AI services is challenging because most businesses view AI as a 'nice-to-have' rather than essential.
OPINION: The sales process for high-ticket AI projects is disproportionately time-consuming for solo operators.
OPINION: Trust built through curiosity, transparency, and authenticity is more valuable than technical expertise alone.
OPINION: Skipping the discovery phase leads to wasted effort solving the wrong business problem.
OPINION: Relying on a single dominant sales channel increases efficiency and focus compared to spreading efforts across many platforms.
OPINION: Success in entrepreneurship comes from commitment and focus, not diversification of effort.
OPINION: The mindset shift from 'will this work?' to 'how could I make this work?' is critical for resilience.
OPINION: Trust in your ability to adapt and solve problems under pressure is essential for long-term survival.
OPINION: Creating one consistent output (e.g., weekly YouTube videos) creates compounding benefits across multiple areas.
OPINION: The emotional rollercoaster of sales cycles can be avoided by adopting a 'money in bank account' mindset.
OPINION: Content creation is more fulfilling than consulting for the speaker, even if less immediately profitable.
OPINION: A focused approach allows all effort to move in one direction, increasing effectiveness.
OPINION: The belief that 'doing less means going in the right direction' reflects a deeper truth about sustainable progress
key_datapoints: DATA: Income dropped from over $10,000 per month to nearly zero after leaving the corporate job.
DATA: 36 discovery calls were conducted over 8 months, resulting in 2 contracts and one $25,000 opportunity.
DATA: YouTube channel grew from 2,000 to 18,000 subscribers in 9 months.
DATA: YouTube revenue increased from $100 to $1,600 in the last 3 months.
DATA: Total revenue from YouTube, Medium blog, and ad hoc consulting calls amounted to $766.38 over 8 months.
DATA: The speaker’s new plan is to publish one YouTube video per week.
DATA: The paid discovery phase was used to scope project requirements and goals before moving to POC.
DATA: The speaker’s content funnel includes reading papers, writing articles, coding examples, interviews, and social media engagement.
DATA: The speaker’s audience growth led to more inbound leads, speaking gigs, and community participation.
DATA: The speaker’s personal brand has grown significantly through consistent content delivery.
DATA: The speaker’s time spent on consulting exceeded expectations, reducing time for personal projects.
DATA: The speaker’s YouTube viewership and engagement have increased steadily since the career pivot.
DATA: The speaker’s content output slowed down during the peak consulting period.
DATA: The speaker’s income from consulting was not sufficient to cover living expenses.
DATA: The speaker’s focus on YouTube has created a clear, measurable goal: one video per week

FACT: McKenzie acquired at least 16 technology consultancies between 2013 and 2023 to expand its digital practice.
FACT: McKenzie has increasingly focused on implementing its own strategic advice across operations, procurement, and supply chain.
FACT: Boston Consulting Group (BCG) has continued robust growth while McKenzie’s expansion has stalled.

FACT: Palanteer deploys engineers directly with clients to embed AI technologies, competing with traditional consulting services.
FACT: OpenAI and other tech firms are beginning to offer consulting-like services by sending teams into client organizations.
FACT: Strategy consulting projects typically involve deep analysis combined with extensive grunt work such as data crunching and slide preparation.
FACT: Junior consultants traditionally handle the bulk of data processing and presentation tasks in strategy projects.
FACT: McKenzie and other firms have trained AI bots on their internal intellectual property libraries for competitive advantage.
FACT: The core strategic advisory business remains healthy despite disruptions from AI and new competitors.
key_opinions: OPINION: McKenzie’s decline reflects not just macroeconomic pressures but also poor execution in talent retention and deployment.

OPINION: The rise of AI-focused firms like Palanteer signals a fundamental shift in how companies approach technology implementation.
OPINION: Tech giants offering consulting services may eventually erode the traditional consultancy model if they maintain client proximity.
OPINION: AI will likely compress consulting fees over time as automation replaces junior-level work.
OPINION: Consultants’ ability to adapt to management fads ensures long-term relevance, even amid disruption.
OPINION: The long-term impact of AI on consulting is underestimated by industry leaders who focus too much on short-term gains.

metadata.title: How I Would Start AI Consulting in 2026 (If I could start over)
metadata.author: Nick Saraev

key_facts: FACT: The speaker has scaled multiple agencies to $160,000 per month in combined revenue.
FACT: The speaker spent hundreds of thousands of dollars of personal money mapping out the optimal path for running an AI consulting agency in 2026.
FACT: The five pillars of an AI consulting agency are marketing, sales, onboarding, fulfillment, and retention.
FACT: Platform sales like Upwork allow consultants to connect directly with business owners who already have a problem and solution in mind.
FACT: Upwork requires high time investment but low capital and low barrier to entry, making it ideal for beginners to generate early revenue.
FACT: Cold email has low ongoing time requirements, medium upfront cost, and high technical barrier to entry, but offers high scalability and leverage.
FACT: Cold DMs on social media platforms like LinkedIn require high time commitment, low capital, and high psychological skill to be effective.
FACT: Communities such as Slack, Reddit, or Maker School require consistent daily presence to build authority and trust over time.
FACT: A successful cold outreach message should include personalization, value proposition, niche relevance, goal alignment, case study, cliffhanger, and clear CTA.
FACT: Discovery in sales involves asking high-ROI questions like 'Why did you book this call?' and 'What is your current goal?'
FACT: The speaker recommends framing pricing at the end of the sales call to maximize perceived value before revealing the cost.
FACT: Onboarding should be frontloaded into a kickoff call to handle access, timelines, communication expectations, and platform setup live.
FACT: Daily check-ins via Slack or WhatsApp reduce client back-and-forth by 90% and improve perception of progress.
FACT: Fulfillment success depends more on managing client perception than on actual delivery quality.
FACT: Delivering systems with a Loom video walkthrough and documentation increases perceived value and supports higher pricing.
key_opinions: OPINION: Marketing is the only thing that matters when starting a business from $0—everything else is a distraction.
OPINION: Cold email is a 'money printer' because it scales independently of time investment once properly set up.
OPINION: Cold DMs are a goldmine if done with hyperpersonalized, informal messaging that feels customized without being overly formal.
OPINION: Communities are a grind, but they can lead to long-term relationships that exceed initial expectations.
OPINION: Sales today is not about manipulation—it's about uncovering pain, solving it, and positioning yourself as the obvious investment.
OPINION: The best time to pitch a follow-up project is immediately after delivering exceptional work, while the client is still emotionally engaged.
OPINION: Overdelivering by 5% triggers reciprocity, significantly increasing the chance of a yes on future projects.
OPINION: Sending a proposal instead of closing on the call leads to better client decisions because they’re both logical and emotional.
OPINION: The real differentiator in consulting isn’t service delivery—it’s managing the perception of that service.
OPINION: Most consultants fail at retention by disappearing after project completion, leaving significant revenue on the table.
OPINION: A client’s ‘I need to think about it’ is rarely about hesitation—it’s usually a hidden objection that needs probing.
OPINION: The highest-performing agencies treat systems like products—packaged with care, presentation, and storytelling.
OPINION: Beginners should start on Upwork because it bypasses the need to sell the problem, solution, and fit.
OPINION: The first cold email campaign will likely fail—but persistence leads to eventual success due to compounding learning.
OPINION: Clients don’t want long updates—they want concise, bullet-pointed progress reports that show momentum.

DATA: One client closed almost $15,000 in revenue from LinkedIn outreach in a single month.
DATA: A supplement company saw $32,000 in additional revenue within one month after system implementation.
DATA: A client saved $50,000 in potential losses through a system that cost $19,000, paying for itself in the first month.
DATA: The speaker has taught the same sales framework to over 6,000 people, many of whom closed deals worth up to $60,000 upfront.
DATA: The speaker’s agencies reached combined monthly revenue of $160,000.
DATA: A single daily update takes approximately 60 seconds per client to send.
DATA: The speaker’s Gumroad library includes templates and automations sold between $2,000 and $15,000.
DATA: Maker School has over 2,500 members actively building AI consulting businesses.
DATA: The speaker’s sales process typically lasts 30 to 45 minutes per call.
DATA: The average client engagement timeline is 3 weeks with three clearly defined milestones.
DATA: The speaker recommends sending daily updates Monday through Friday to maintain client trust.
DATA: A successful onboarding kickoff call can be completed in under 30 minutes.
DATA: The speaker’s proposal system uses automatic follow-ups over 7–14 days with time-limited offers.
DATA: The speaker claims lifetime value of clients can double simply by improving communication consistency.

‫כשזה נוגע לבינה מלאכותית.‬ ‫מצד אחד, יש לנו הכחשה - האמונה שבינה‬
‫מלאכותית לא יכולה לעשות את העבודה שלי,‬ ‫או שאין לנו זמן לבחון את הטכנולוגיה הזו.‬ ‫זה מקום מסוכן להיות בו.‬ ‫אימרה נפוצה היא שבינה מלאכותית‬
‫לא תיקח לך את העבודה,‬ ‫אבל אנשים שמשתמשים בה כן ייקחו.‬ ‫זה נכון גם לגבי פרטים וגם לגבי חברות.‬ ‫מצד שני, יש לנו פאניקה ויאוש -‬ ‫האמונה שבינה מלאכותית תגזול ממני‬
‫את העבודה לא משנה מה,‬ ‫שהיא תגרום לחברה שלי לפשוט רגל.‬ ‫אף אחד מסוג החשיבה האלה לא מועיל.‬ ‫אז אני מציע נקודת אמצע,‬
‫חשיבה חיובית מאוזנת.‬ ‫בינה מלאכותית תהפוך אותי, את הצוות שלי‬
‫ואת החברה שלי ליצרנים בטירוף.‬ ‫באופן אישי, אני מרגיש שהשגתי‬
‫כוחות-על בחשיבה הזו.‬ ‫אני יכול להגיע מרעיון לתוצאה‬
‫בזמן קצר בהרבה.‬ ‫אני יכול להתרכז יותר במה שאני רוצה להשיג‬
‫ופחות בעבודה השחורה של בניית דברים.‬ ‫ואני גם לומד הרבה יותר מהר.‬ ‫זה כמו להחזיק במנטור מדהים‬
‫שנמצא איתי כל הזמן.‬ ‫החשיבה הזו לא רק מרגישה טוב‬ ‫אלא מציידת אתכם לעתיד,‬ ‫מפחיתה את הסבירות שתאבדו‬
‫את העבודה שלכם או את החברה שלכם,‬ ‫ומעלה את הסבירות שתשגשגו בעידן‬
‫של בינה מלאכותית למרות אי-הוודאות.‬ ‫אז שאלה חשובה אחת היא - האם תפקיד מסוים‬
‫עדיין נדרש בעידן של בינה מלאכותית?‬ ‫לדוגמה, האם רופאים‬
‫עדיין נדרשים, מפתחים,‬ ‫עורכי דין, מנכ"לים, מה שלא יהיה?‬ ‫השאלה הזו הופכת רלוונטית יותר ויותר‬
‫ככל שיכולות הבינה המלאכותית משתפרות.‬ ‫עבודות מסוימות בטוח יעלמו.‬ ‫אבל אני חושב שרוב התפקידים‬
‫של בני האדם עדיין נדרשים.‬ ‫מישהו עם ידע בתחום מסוים עדיין צריך להחליט‬
‫מה לשאול את הבינה המלאכותית,‬ ‫איך לעצב את הפרומפט,‬
‫איזה הקשר לספק‬ ‫ואיך להעריך את התוצאה.‬ ‫מודלים של בינה מלאכותית‬
‫אינם מושלמים.‬ ‫הם יכולים להיות מבריקים לפעמים,‬ ‫אבל לפעמים גם טיפשיים מאוד.‬ ‫הם יכולים לפעמים להזות‬
‫ולספק מידע מפוברק‬ ‫באופן משכנע מאוד.‬ ‫אז מתי צריך לסמוך על תשובה‬
‫של בינה מלאכותית?‬ ‫מתי אתם צריכים לבדוק‬
‫או לבצע עבודה בעצמכם?‬ ‫מה לגבי ציות לחוק, אבטחת מידע?‬ ‫איזה מידע נוכל להזין לתוך מודל‬
‫בינה מלאכותית ואיפה המידע מאוחסן?‬ ‫נדרש מומחה בן אנוש‬
‫כדי לקבל את ההחלטות האלה‬ ‫ולפצות על חולשת מודל הבינה המלאכותית.‬ ‫אז אני ממליץ לחשוב על בינה מלאכותית‬
‫כמו על עמית לעבודה,‬ ‫גאון, אבל גם חריג עם מוזרויות אישיות‬ ‫שעליכם ללמוד לעבוד איתו.‬ ‫עליכם לזהות מתי העמית שלכם שיכור.‬ ‫כרופא, עמית הבינה המלאכותית שלי‬
‫יכול לעזור לי לאבחן מחלות נדירות‬ ‫שלא ידעתי אפילו על קיומן.‬ ‫כעורך דין, עמית הבינה המלאכותית שלי‬
‫יכול לערוך מחקר בחוק ולערוך בקרה על חוזים‬ ‫ומאפשר לי יותר זמן עם הלקוח שלי.‬ ‫כמורה, עמית הבינה המלאכותית שלי‬
‫יכול לתת ציונים על מבחנים,‬ ‫לעזור להפיק תוכן לקורסים,‬ ‫לספק תמיכה אישית לסטודנטים, וכו'.‬ ‫ואם אינכם בטוחים איך הוא יכול‬
‫לעזור לכם, פשוט תשאלו אותו.‬ ‫אני עובד בתור X. איך תוכל לעזור לי?‬ ‫באופן כללי, אני מוצא ששילוב בני אדם‬
‫ושל בינה מלאכותית‬ ‫זה המקום שבו נמצא הקסם.‬ ‫חשוב להבחין בין המודלים‬ ‫לבין המוצרים שבונים עליהם.‬ ‫כמשתמשים, אתם לא‬
‫באים במגע ישיר עם המודל.‬ ‫במקום זה, אתם באים במגע‬
‫עם מוצר באתר או באפליקציה‬ ‫והוא מדבר עם המודל מאחורי הקלעים.‬ ‫מוצרים מספקים ממשק משתמש‬
‫ומוסיפים יכולות ונתונים‬ ‫שאינם חלק מהמוצר עצמו.‬ ‫לדוגמה, המוצר של ChatGPT משמר את היסטוריית ההודעות שלכם‬ ‫בזמן שה-GPT4 כשלעצמו‬
‫לא כולל היסטוריית הודעות.‬ ‫כמפתחים, תוכלו להשתמש במודלים האלה‬ ‫כדי לבנות מוצרים ומאפיינים‬
‫של בינה מלאכותית בעצמכם.‬ ‫לדוגמה, בואו נגיד שיש לכם‬
‫אתר ללמידה מקוונת -‬ ‫תוכלו להוסיף צ'אטבוט למענה‬
‫על שאלות לגבי הקורסים,‬ ‫או חברת גיוס -‬ ‫אולי תבנו כלים של בינה מלאכותית‬
‫כדי לעזור בהערכת מועמדים.‬ ‫בשני המקרים האלה, המשתמשים שלכם‬
‫באים במגע עם המוצרים שלכם‬ ‫ואז המוצרים באים במגע עם המודל.‬ ‫זה נעשה באמצעות API,‬ ‫ממשקי תכנות אפליקציות,‬ ‫המאפשרים לקוד שלכם‬
‫לדבר עם המודל.‬ ‫אז הנה דוגמה פשוטה לשימוש ב-API‬
‫של בינה מלאכותית פתוחה כדי לדבר עם GPT.‬ ‫לא צריך הרבה קוד.‬ ‫והנה דוגמה אחרת של‬ ‫הערכת המועמדים האוטומטית‬
‫שדיברתי עליה.‬ ‫היא לוקחת תיאור תפקיד‬
‫וערימה של קו"ח בתיקייה‬ ‫ומעריכה כל מועמד אוטומטית.‬ ‫ודרך אגב, הקוד עצמו‬
‫נכתב על ידי בינה מלאכותית.‬ ‫כמפתחי מוצר, תוכלו להשתמש במודלים‬
‫של בינה מלאכותית‬ ‫כמו במוח חיצוני כדי להחדיר‬
‫אינטליגנציה לתוך המוצר שלכם.‬ ‫עוצמתי ביותר.‬ ‫כדי להשתמש בבינה מלאכותית יוצרת‬
‫באופן אפקטיבי,‬ ‫תצטרכו להשתפר בהנדסת פרומפטים‬ ‫או עיצוב פרומפטים,‬
‫כפי שאני מעדיף לקרוא לזה.‬ ‫המיומנות הזו נדרשת גם כמשתמש‬
‫וגם כמפתח מוצר,‬ ‫בגלל שבשני המקרים‬ ‫תצטרכו לייצר פרומפטים אפקטיביים‬ ‫המפיקים תוצאות שימושיות‬
‫מתוך מודל בינה מלאכותית.‬ ‫הנה דוגמה.‬ ‫בואו נאמר שאני רוצה לעזור לתכנן סדנה.‬ ‫לא סביר שהפרומפט הזה יפיק תוצאות‬ ‫בגלל שלא משנה כמה‬
‫הבינה המלאכותית חכמה,‬ ‫אם היא לא יודעת מה ההקשר‬
‫של הסדנה שלי‬ ‫היא יכולה רק לתת‬
‫המלצות מעורפלות ברמה גבוהה.‬ ‫הפרומפט השני טוב יותר.‬ ‫עכשיו סיפקתי הקשר.‬ ‫זה בדרך כלל נעשה באופן חזרתי.‬ ‫כתבו פרומפט, התבוננו בתוצאה,‬ ‫הוסיפו פרומפט נוסף‬
‫כדי לספק מידע נוסף,‬ ‫או ערכו את הפרומפט המקורי,‬ ‫וחזרו על זה עד שתקבלו תוצאה טובה.‬ ‫בגישה השלישית הזו,‬ ‫אני מבקש לראיין אותי.‬ ‫אז במקום שאני אספק‬
‫הקשר נרחב מראש,‬ ‫אני בעצם אומר - "מה אתה צריך לדעת‬
‫כדי לעזור לי?"‬ ‫ואז זה יציע סדר יום לסדנה.‬ ‫לעתים קרובות אני משלב בין השניים.‬ ‫אני מספק הקשר מועט,‬ ‫ואז אני אומר לזה לשאול אותי‬
‫אם צריך עוד מידע.‬ ‫אלה רק דוגמאות של‬
‫טכניקות הנדסת פרומפטים.‬ ‫אז באופן כללי, ככל שתשתפרו‬
‫בהנדסת פרומפטים,‬ ‫תקבלו תוצאות מהירות וטובות יותר‬
‫מהבינה המלאכותית.‬ ‫יש קורסים רבים, ספרים, סרטונים, מאמרים‬ ‫שיעזרו לכם ללמוד את זה,‬ ‫אבל הדבר החשוב ביותר‬
‫הוא תרגול ולמידה באמצעות עשייה.‬ ‫תוצר לוואי נחמד‬ ‫הוא שתהפכו טובים יותר‬
‫בתקשורת באופן כללי‬ ‫כי הנדסת פרומפטים בעצם מסתמכת‬ ‫על בהירות ותקשורת אפקטיבית.‬ ‫אני חושב שהגבול הבא שאותו נחצה‬
‫בבינה מלאכותית יוצרת‬ ‫הוא סוכנים עצמאיים עם כלים.‬ ‫אלה הן ישויות תוכנה של בינה מלאכותית‬
‫שפועלות בעצמן‬ ‫במקום רק לשבת ולחכות‬ ‫שתזינו לתוכן פרומפטים כל הזמן.‬ ‫אז אתם יורדים למרתף לאיינשטיין שלכם‬ ‫ועושים מה שמנהיג טוב‬
‫היה עושה עבור צוות.‬ ‫אתם נותנים משימה ברמה גבוהה‬
‫ואת הכלים הנדרשים לביצועה,‬ ‫ואז פותחים את הדלת‬
‫ונותנים לו לנהל את עצמו,‬ ‫מבלי להתערב בכל פרט.‬ ‫הכלים יוכלו להיות דברים כמו גישה לאינטרנט,‬ ‫גישה לכסף, היכולת לשלוח ולקבל הודעות,‬ ‫להזמין פיצה, או מה שלא יהיה.‬ ‫לשם כך, הנדסת פרומפטים‬
‫תהפוך לחשובה אפילו יותר‬ ‫כי הסוכן בעל הכלים שלכם‬
‫יוכל לעשות הרבה טוב‬ ‫או ליצור הרבה נזק, תלוי כמה טוב‬
‫תעצבו את הגדרת המשימה.‬ ‫בסדר, בואו נסכם.‬ ‫הנה הדברים המרכזיים‬
‫שאני מקווה שתזכרו מהסרטון הזה.‬ ‫בינה מלאכותית יוצרת‬
‫היא כלי יעיל שיכול לעזור לכם,‬ ‫לצוות שלכם, ולחברה שלכם‬
‫בצורה נרחבת.‬ ‫ככל שתבינו אותו טוב יותר‬ ‫סביר יותר שזו תהיה הזדמנות ולא איום.‬ ‫בינה מלאכותית יוצרת‬
‫היא עוצמתית יותר משאתם חושבים.‬ ‫המגבלה הגדולה ביותר‬
‫היא לא הטכנולוגיה,‬ ‫אלא הדימיון שלכם,‬ ‫כלומר, מה אני יכול לעשות,‬ ‫ומיומנות הנדסת הפרומפטים שלכם.‬ ‫איך אני עושה את זה?‬ ‫עיצוב או הנדסת פרומטים‬
‫היא מיומנות חיונית.‬ ‫כמו כל מיומנות חדשה,‬ ‫קבלו את העובדה שתהיו גרועים בזה בהתחלה,‬ ‫אבל תשתפרו עם הזמן בעזרת תרגול מכוון.‬ ‫אז העצה הטובה ביותר שלי היא להתנסות.‬ ‫שלבו את זה ביום-יום שלכם‬ ‫והלמידה תתרחש אוטומטית.‬ ‫מקווה שהסרטון הזה עוזר.‬ ‫תודה שצפיתם.‬ תרגום: המרכז האקדמי רופין

key_facts: FACT: בינה מלאכותית יוצרת היא טכנולוגיה שמייצרת תוכן מקורי חדש, בניגוד לבינה מלאכותית מסורתית שנועדה לסדר או לזהות תוכן קיים.

FACT: מודלים של בינה מלאכותית יכולים לייצר תכנים מסוגים שונים – טקסט, תמונות, שמע, ווידאו – בהתאם לסוג המודל.
FACT: מודלים של טקסט-תמונה יוצרים תמונות לפי תיאורים מילוליים, תוך אפשרות לבחור סגנון.
FACT: מודלים של טקסט-שמע יוצרים מוסיקה או צלילים מתוך פרומפטים מילוליים.
FACT: מודלים של טקסט-וידאו יוצרים סרטונים שלמים מתוך תיאורים מילוליים.

FACT: מודלים של בינה מלאכותית יכולים להפיק קוד תוכנה, סיכומים, תרגום, כתיבת מאמרים, ותכנון אירועים.
FACT: מודלים של בינה מלאכותית יכולים לסייע לרופאים, עורך דין, מורים, ומנהלי עסקים במשימות יומיומיות.
FACT: מודלים של בינה מלאכותית יכולים להפוך לספקים של מידע מפוברק או מוטעה, גם אם זה נשמע משכנע.
FACT: מודלים של בינה מלאכותית יכולים להשתפר באופן מתמשך בעתיד, אך כיום הם כמעט קבועים לאחר האימון הראשוני.
key_opinions: OPINION: הבינה המלאכותית יוצרת היא לא רק כלי, אלא עמית עבודה שיכול לשפר את היכולות האינטלקטואליות של האדם.
OPINION: המגבלה העיקרית של הבינה המלאכותית היא לא הטכנולוגיה, אלא הדמיון והיכולת של האדם לתקשר עם המודל בצורה יעילה.
OPINION: הנדסת פרומפטים היא מיומנות חיונית כמו קריאה וכתיבה, וחייבת להיות חלק מהתהליך של עבודה מודרנית.
OPINION: אנשים שמשתמשים בבינה מלאכותית יוצרים יתרון משמעותי על פני אלה שמתעלמים ממנה.
OPINION: הבינה המלאכותית לא תחליף את האדם, אלא תהפוך אותו ליצרן חזק יותר, במיוחד כשיש שילוב בין אדם למודל.
OPINION: תחושת הפאניקה או ההכחשה לגבי הבינה המלאכותית מונעת מאמץ אמיתי ומובילה להפסדים בעידן החדש.
OPINION: סוכנים עצמאיים עם כלים הם הגבול הבא של הבינה המלאכותית – ישויות שמבצעות משימות מורכבות ללא התערבות מתמדת.
OPINION: מודלים של בינה מלאכותית יכולים להיות מבריקים, אך גם טיפשיים או מוטעים – לכן נדרשת ביקורת אנושית.
OPINION: שילוב בין אדם למודל הוא המקום שבו נוצרת הערך האמיתי, ולא מנגנון של חילוף או תחרות.
OPINION: מודלים של בינה מלאכותית לא צריכים להיות מושלמים כדי להיות שימושיים – חשוב להבין איך להשתמש בהם בצורה אפקטיבית.

si的各种版本到底有什么区别？他的回答通常会比较一般，它是有一些迷惑性的答案。所以说这确的流程应该是先让他给出来一个准确的答案，等他回答完之后，你再让他用通俗的易懂的话去解释，效果就会更好一些啊。还是刚才那个例子，你应该先问用专业的术语解释deep的不同版本的区别。哎，等他回答完这一次之后，你再和A去说，哎，你把刚才的话用通俗易懂的话再解释一遍，那这样子的话它的效果会好得多。第二，无论问什么都要明确告诉A眼影的目的是什么。我举个例子，比如说你想问如何做好自媒体视频的封面，你不能直接这么问，你必须得告诉他，我现在希望做一个自媒体视频的封面，目的是提高封标点击率啊，如果你还有更多的需求的话，比如我还想让封面制作不要那么难，我还不想用付费的方式啊，你也都给他列出来。这样子的话也就会以你这些目的为核心去找方法，而不是天马行空的去想象一些你不需要的技巧，这样子就能大大降低你和AI多轮对话的次数，因为对话的轮次一多，AI反而也容易跑偏，特别是在AI开启深入思考和思维链的时候。给他一个明确的目标和奔头，他才能够给你更加正确的答案。这里还有个建议，你不需要去背那些网上流传的提示词模板啊，他们花里胡哨呢，那些东西过于复杂，既不现实，你找起来也很费劲，估具有实操性。其实提示词的本质很简单，你只需要抓住三个根本的点就可以了。你的背景你要做什么，以及你做这些东西的效果要达成什么样子。就比如说我是一个刚做十天自媒体的运营，需要设计一款美食教程的封面，目标是在20天内达到涨粉1000来带货啊，这就是背景任务加成效三个不同的点。你只要能把这三个不同的点都写到了，那么就可以让A输出一个只少90分以上的答案。第三，如果你的问题存在多个冲突的目标，那要用辩论的方式让A们分窗口讨论，再让一个A去裁决。就比如说我既想让我的自媒体方面吸引眼球，我又想让他显得专业和严谨。那这个时候呢我的方法就是让A和A之间进行辩论，最后由一个A进行开决。具体的方法是这样的，你先开一个窗口，你就问这个A如果我要做一个自媒体封面，希望他能够吸引眼球，我该怎么做？然后他给你输出来一个答案，这个时候呢你再开一个新窗口，然后你问他我现在想要做一个自媒体封面，希望他能够专业。哎，这个时候改成专业了啊，我该怎么做？拿到这两个答案之后，然后再打开第三个窗口，告诉我A言，我希望让我的自媒体封面既能提高点击率，吸引眼球，又能体现我的专业性。但是我之前已经获得两个专家的不同策略，同时你得把这两个不同的这个答案给他，放在下面去问他你应该怎么去取舍。这样子的话呢就相当于A就可以把这A的这个专业性，还有这个B的这个吸引眼球都综合起来，给你一个权衡的取舍的答案，这样子这个答案就会更加准确一些。第四，你想的明白A才能答的明白。无论我们使用什么技巧，最根本的还是要求我们自己的头脑都更加清醒。我们必须要明白，A只是放大你的思路的一个工具，它不能根本上的知道你想要什么。所有这一切的方法包括多轮对话，什么优化提示词啊，还有很多那种其他的方法。最终的目的都是为了能够让我们自己能够想的明白。其实有的人他能让AI回答的更好，本质上就是他比你想的更加明白一些。A是一个你越聪明他就越聪明的工具。就拿刚才那个例子，如果你使用了AI的辩论法之后，发现他的答案还是更偏向于吸引眼球。那这个时候呢，如果你的心理已经产生了一个答案，就是说你更希望你产生一个专业性的这么一个封面。那这个时候是不是有好办了？说明你的头脑已经很清醒了啊，已经明确了你就想要这个专业性，而非是那个博眼球。这个时候你就可以直接给A说，看了你答案之后，我感觉我更倾向于专业性。你再重新给我提一次你的建议，那这个时候A他的建议就会很好了。其实啊你和这个AI去沟通，就像是你和设计师去沟通一样，你总得自己先勾勒出来一个大体的框架，对方才能够和你去讨论。很多人之所以得不到好的答案，并不是AI不够好。而他们自己脑子里面没有想明白，那么如何才能让自己想明白呢？在想明白之前需要做第零步，就是一定要见多识广。你的脑子里面一定要先有东西。比如说你要做一个封面图，那么你的脑子里面如果没有任何封面图的概念，你就想象不出来到底要做什么样子的。你必须先去看大量不同的风格的案例。比如说什么左右并置啊，什么把人物放大呀，什么那个before after ter等等。这样的格式你见的足够多了。你脑子里面有了蓝图，这个时候呢你再给A具体需求，A就可以给你提出来更好的建议。所以那些能把AI用的好的人，往往是那些更加见多识广的人。第五，想不明白让AI怎么做，那要通过多轮对话和实验的方式来实现。有时候你会发现我们靠抽象的思维，还有多轮对话也很难去理清楚我们的思路。比如说我之前有遇到过，我可以去给大家讲科研知识，也可以给大家讲生活技巧，也可以去科普的AI的知识我不能说非常擅长，但又有一些个人经验啊，我其实又很纠结到底要做哪一个。这个时候呢光想是没有用的，你们其实也不一定知道你到底会做哪一个啊，你必须得去实践里去试。这个时候呢你就多试一试嘛，是吧，看大家喜欢哪一个啊，或者是说哪些东西对大家来说的反馈更好一些。那这样子的话呢，你就可以带着你的反馈去和AI去讨论，这就形成了一个认识实践在认识的过程啊，这样子的话你才可以在实践中为AI提供新的一些灵感。这样子AI才可以给你指出来更好的路径，而不是说在脑子里面进行空想。这样子你也不知道AI也不知道当你能从实践中获得更多的数据，那么你再和A去讨论，那他就会给你更加客观还有准确的答案。所以以上就是我让A回答更好的五个方法，我们下期再见。

AI到底怎么用？为什么别人能用AI写报告写ppt但是自己用AI写出来的东西交上去肯定会埃批，如果你也想知道大神到底是怎么用AI的，AI的提问基本结构应该是什么样的？如何让你的AI也能随心所欲的生成你想要的东西，那本期视频一定值得你看到。最后我会把当前AI领先的使用技巧都告诉你，让你在AI时代来临之际快人一步。我是国有咬摇大叔，一个未来将专注于AI领域的探路人，如果你也对AI感兴趣，记得关注我的频道，这样你就不会错过AI最新的干货技巧。现在我们开始AI回答的不专业，第一个问题就是没有做AI的角色定义。比如你想要AI帮你制定一个减肥饮食计划，你直接问帮我制定一个减肥饮食计划，你得到的答案就会很粗糙。虽然计划是给你了，但是细细一读会发现几乎无法执行。那现在我们让他扮演一个营养学专家，再帮我制定一份饮食计划，答案就会完全不同。我们的提示语这样写，现在你扮演一个营养学专家，招写一下这个角色的一些背景信息。比如教育背景、职业资格、职业经历和研究领域。案例中的这个教育背景是营养学博士，职业资格是注册营养师，职业经历是加入营养学会巴拉巴拉，研究领域是饮食、减肥等等。让AI带入一个角色之后，我们再问原来那个问题，帮我制定一个减肥饮食计划，你会发现得到了一个完全不同的答案。这次的回答因为我没有告诉她我的个人信息，所以他开篇就告诉我这是一个相对通用的减肥饮食计划。在这个计划里他明确的告诉我应该吃几顿，每顿吃什么，以及具体吃多少，并且告诉我为什么要这样吃，吃这个东西的目的是什么。为了方便对比，我们单独把早餐计划拿出来看一下，在没有做角色定义之前，给到的计划很粗糙，比如应该吃一碗麦片，但完全没有告诉我一碗是多大一碗。在角色定义之后，他告诉我要吃两个鸡蛋、40克麦片以及200毫升的低脂牛奶或者豆浆，并且告诉我吃燕麦片是复合碳水化合物，提供慢释放的能量等等。第二份减肥饮食计划就相当的专业了。那现在问题来了，应该如何去做这个角色的定义呢？现在是制定减肥饮食计划，那我们很清楚他需要扮演一个营养师。那如果我需要他帮我分析化妆品的成分表，那请问她应该扮演什么人呢？这就是个问题。所以角色定义的第一步就是根据问题匹配角色。在不知道扮演什么样人的时候，我首先应该问A我想要解读和分析化妆品成分，请问我应该咨询什么样的专业人士？他就会给到我一个答案，这提供了六个角色，我觉得这六个角色都挺不错的。我们选第一个化妆品化学家。那问题来了，如果只是给一句请你扮演一个化妆品化学家显然是不够的。如果你的AI有一个明确的身份背景，那他在回答你真正想要知道的问题的时候，就会更加的专业，你得到的答案也会更加的满意。现在第二步就是构建A身份背景，我们这样提示A请帮我虚构一个化妆品化学家的身份背景，要包括教育背景、职业资格、职业经历和研究领域，你就会得到一个很全面的角色背景信息。第三步就是利用特定结构组成提示语，我们选取其中的部分信息，根据特定结构写一个背景信息赋予的提示语。这个特定结构包括两个部分，第一个部分是一句话，就是请你扮演一个化妆品化学家。第二个部分就是具体的背景信息，包括四个部分，分别是教育背景、职业资格、职业经历和研究领域。在设定好AI的身份背景后，现在你可以提出你真正想要问的问题，并且获得专业的答案。总结一下AI的角色设定提问有四个步骤，分别是根据问题匹配角色、虚构角色身份背景、利用特定结构组成提示语，最后是提出你之人想要问的问题，这就是今天教你的第一招，通过AI角色设定优化回答，还有更多的AI操作方法，比如如何运用qa模型提问、循环提问模型等等。因为时长有限，更多的技巧会在之后的视频一一呈现，并且这些技巧并不仅限于切GPT的使用，国内的AI同样使用，比如通义千问、文心一言、小爱同学、小布助手等等，那本期视频就先到这里，感谢你的点赞。三连关注国小小二大叔，做AI时代的先行者。
